q: What are the symptoms of vaginitis?
a: Symptoms of vaginitis include: an itchy or sore vagina, vaginal discharge that's a different color, smell or thickness to usual, vaginal dryness, pain when peeing or having sex, light vaginal bleeding or spotting, sore, swollen or cracked skin around the vagina. You might not have all these symptoms.

q: What are the common causes of vaginitis?
a: Common causes of vaginitis include thrush (white and lumpy discharge, itching, and soreness), sexually transmitted infections like trichomoniasis or chlamydia (yellow, green, or smelly discharge, pain when peeing or having sex), hormone changes from menopause, breastfeeding or some types of contraception (dry, itchy vagina, and pain during sex), and skin conditions like eczema or lichen planus (itchy, sore patches around the vagina and on other parts of the body). Vaginitis can also be caused by irritation, injury to the vagina, or something in the vagina.

q: When should I see a doctor for vaginitis?
a: You should see a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if you have symptoms of vaginitis for the first time, if you've had vaginitis before but the symptoms are bothering you a lot, are different than usual, or are not getting better, if you have unusual vaginal discharge, if you have symptoms of vaginitis after having sex with a new partner, or if you have other symptoms like feeling hot and shivery or pain in your lower tummy. It's important not to have sex until you've seen a doctor or nurse, as it could be a sexually transmitted infection.

q: What happens during an appointment for vaginitis?
a: During an appointment for vaginitis, a doctor or nurse may ask about your sexual partners, look at the skin around your vagina, and perform a pelvic examination. For a pelvic examination, you'll be asked to remove your underwear and lie on your back. The doctor or nurse will gently insert a speculum into your vagina to hold it open and may take a swab to check for infections.

q: What treatments are available for vaginitis?
a: The treatment for vaginitis depends on the cause. For example, you may need antifungal medicine for thrush, antibiotics for a sexually transmitted infection, vaginal moisturizers, lubricants, or hormone treatment for menopause symptoms, or steroid medicine for a skin condition.

q: What can I do to help ease symptoms of vaginitis?
a: To help ease symptoms of vaginitis, you can wash around your vagina with water and dry thoroughly, wear loose, cotton underwear, use pads instead of tampons when you're on your period, and use condoms and lubrication when having sex. It's important not to clean inside your vagina (douching), have hot baths, or use scented hygiene products in or around your vagina.
